qas.question: Who made up most unions between Europeans and natives?

answers.text: European men and Indigenous American women

qas.question: What factor affected the ability of a child to be in a tribe?

answers.text: the kinship system of the woman's tribe

qas.question: How could a white child be considered a member of the Omaha tribe?

answers.text: adopted into the tribe by an adult male

qas.question: What did not dictate how easily a woman's children would be assimilated into a tribe?
What kind of systems did tribes in the Northwest have?
Who did the Creek not give status in their mother's tribes?
Who was not considered white to the Omaha?

context: In the early 19th century, the Indigenous American woman <b5_0>Sacagawea<b5_0/>, who would help translate for and guide the Lewis and Clark Expedition in the West, married the <a0_0>French trapper Toussaint Charbonneau<a0_0/>. Most marriages between Europeans and Indigenous Americans were between <a1_0>European men and Indigenous American women<a1_0/>. Depending on <a2_0>the <b6_0>kinship system<b6_0/> of the woman's tribe<a2_0/>, their children would be more or less easily assimilated into the tribe. Nations that had <b7_0>matrilineal<b7_0/> systems, such as the <a3_0>Creek and Cherokee<a3_0/> in the Southeast, gave the <b8_0>mixed-race children<b8_0/> status in their mother's clans and tribes. If the tribe had a patrilineal system, like the Omaha, the <b9_0>children of white fathers<b9_0/> were considered white. Unless they were specifically <a4_0>adopted into the tribe by an adult male<a4_0/>, they could have no social status in it.
